summary: This paper presents a method for detecting alcohol consumption using periocular near-infrared (NIR) images and a novel Fused Capsule Network (F-CapsNet) architecture. The approach leverages changes in iris and pupil dynamics caused by alcohol's effects on the central nervous system. A new dataset of 3,000 NIR images from 30 volunteers (with and without alcohol) was collected under controlled conditions. The proposed F-CapsNet achieved 92.3% accuracy, outperforming traditional CNNs and SVMs, and is suitable for real-time and mobile deployment due to its reduced parameter count. The study demonstrates the feasibility of camera-based, real-time alcohol impairment detection using NIR imaging.

core.paper_title: Alcohol Consumption Detection from Periocular NIR Images Using Capsule Network
core.real_time_capability: Yes (algorithm designed for real-time and mobile deployment)
core.sample_size: 30 subjects, 3,000 NIR images (expanded to 12,000 with augmentation)
core.environment: Controlled indoor environment (constant lighting, 200 lux, fixed camera distances)
core.relevance_reason: Directly addresses real-time alcohol impairment detection using NIR camera images and advanced deep learning, with a dedicated dataset and high reported accuracy.

dataset.name: IAL-I
dataset.composition: 30 volunteers (24 male, 6 female), ages 25-50, 5 sessions (pre- and post-alcohol at 15, 30, 45, 60 min), 10 images per eye per session
dataset.protocol: 200ml alcohol (42%) consumed, images captured at intervals

algorithm.feature_extraction: Separate convolutional blocks for alcohol/no-alcohol, fused before capsule layers

key_findings.pupil_iris_ratio: Not sufficient alone for reliable alcohol detection due to overlapping distributions
key_findings.deep learning: F-CapsNet significantly outperforms traditional ML and CNNs for this task

limitations.non-visual_methods: Not used; focus is exclusively on NIR imaging
limitations.generalizability: Dataset size is moderate; further validation in real-world, less controlled settings needed

visualization.explainability: GradCAM++ used to highlight iris and periocular regions as most relevant for classification

details.application: Fitness for Duty (FFD) assessment in safety-critical industries
